post.body:
# Git Center - GitHub for ZeroNet
**Git Center** is a decentralized hosting platform for Git repositories. We provide several collaboration features such as bug tracking for every project, and private and public repositories.

## Why Git Center?
Currently **Git Center** is the only repository hosting in ZeroNet. This is like 0git, but better: a full alternative to GitHub.

## Cool! How can I access it?
Full link: [http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/)
Currently you can also use [0sh.bit/?GitCenter](/0sh.bit/?GitCenter)
@Kaffie: Could you please add [Git Center](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t) - an alternative to GitHub - to Kaffiene?

## Git Center Update
1. Fixed bugs
2. Added "Upload file" feature. You have to press `New file`, then choose path and commit message, then press `Upload and commit` button.

GitHub mirror: https://github.com/imachug/gitcenter
GitLab mirror: https://gitlab.com/imachug/gitcenter
Preview

## Git Center Update

Fixed hooks. A few words about what they are (currently working only on Windows, but that's a bug in ZeroNet):
1. You can enable them for your repository in `Settings` tab. You have to sign and publish changes after that.
2. They simplify `git push`. If you enable them and set `zeronet.home` git variable, `git push` will automatically sign & publish your repository.
3. How it works? Your `users.json` is read, then zeronet.py, zeronet.exe or whatever is ran to sign and publish your repository.

## Git Center Update
I couldn't work for this project for some days, now I fixed some issues.

Maintainers don't work, so they were removed. Signing now works as signing with site's private key. So, you have to share repository private key with other maintainers.

I won't be able to update my repos to make them work, but @Krixano: 's repos' are be downloadable.
@Nofish: Are you planning on adding ZeroNet to Git Center?

## Git Center Update

Added stars. Now you can star any repository that is in index (you cannot star private repositories).

Dark theme for Git Center by @Binchan:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/1510560577
@Nofish: Have you thought about `Repost` button on ZeroMe?
Whoever posted `BitTorrent Share` to Git Center, could please resign and republish your repository? Currently it's not downloadable.

Added repository index sorting by stars! And star count is shown.

@BinChan: Please update your dark theme for this.

---

Working on searching.
@Herp: Guess you have a problem. You are following fake nof**t**sh instead of nof**i**sh.

## Git Center Update

Not such a big feature, but just added issue/PR mentioning!
@Bwoi: @Alex: Looks like you are finally alive. Could you resign your Git Center Repo please (RVRE)?
@BinChan: Sorry for asking you again, but could you please enchat your dark theme and unset `font-size: 32px` for repo title? It was changed to 28px for a while because then repo name overflows.

Devs!

Help with SQL!

```sql
SELECT tbl.type AS type, tbl.date_added AS date_added, tbl.title AS title, tbl.action AS body, tbl.url AS url FROM (
			SELECT
				'comment' AS type, issue_actions.date_added AS date_added, issues_json.title AS title, issue_actions.action AS action, issue_actions.param AS param, 'repo/issues/view/?' || issues_json.site || '/' || issues_json.id || '@' || REPLACE(issues_json.directory, 'data/users/', '') AS url
			FROM
				issue_actions
			LEFT JOIN
				(SELECT id, title, body, json_id, site, directory FROM issues LEFT JOIN json USING (json_id)) AS issues_json
			ON
				(issue_actions.issue_id = issues_json.id AND issue_actions.issue_json = issues_json.directory)
			LEFT JOIN
				(SELECT cert_user_id, json_id AS action_json_id FROM json) AS action_json
			ON
				(action_json.action_json_id = issue_actions.json_id)
			WHERE
				issues_json.site IN (:params) AND issue_actions.json_id IN (SELECT json_id FROM json WHERE json.site = issues_json.site)
			
			UNION ALL
			
			SELECT
				'comment' AS type, pull_request_actions.date_added AS date_added, pull_requests_json.title AS title, pull_request_actions.action AS action, pull_request_actions.param AS param, 'repo/pull-requests/view/?' || pull_requests_json.site || '/' || pull_requests_json.id || '@' || REPLACE(pull_requests_json.directory, 'data/users/', '') AS url
			FROM
				pull_request_actions
			LEFT JOIN
				(SELECT id, title, body, json_id, site, directory FROM pull_requests LEFT JOIN json USING (json_id)) AS pull_requests_json
			ON
				(pull_request_actions.pull_request_id = pull_requests_json.id AND pull_request_actions.pull_request_json = pull_requests_json.directory)
			LEFT JOIN
				(SELECT cert_user_id, json_id AS action_json_id FROM json) AS action_json
			ON
				(action_json.action_json_id = pull_request_actions.json_id)
			WHERE
				pull_requests_json.site IN (:params) AND pull_request_actions.json_id IN (SELECT json_id FROM json WHERE json.site = pull_requests_json.site)
		) AS tbl
```

For directory structure, please refer to dbschema.json [on GitHub <external>](https://github.com/imachug/gitcenter/blob/issue-9-164x9q7/src/dbschema.json) or [on Git Center <zeronet>](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?18r929Hq8hE5Pi9Zf7ovMQVyn3WcGfxMgu/src/dbschema.json@issue-9-164x9q7).

---

I am getting this error in ZeroNet console:

```sql
'SELECT'
```

Seriously.

Interestingly, after changing `:params` to `"1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t"` and running that query locally (via SQLiteStudio) on my database, I get correct results and no error.

## Git Center Update

Brought to my attention by @空澄砂夜: aka Sorasumi Sayo. Added `[ ]` / `[x]` / `[v]` checkboxes support in markdown by [commit c73bead](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/commit/?18r929Hq8hE5Pi9Zf7ovMQVyn3WcGfxMgu/c73bead539eecffe33908bade25368aaa6326652).

Not editable by clicking yet, if you have any ideas how to implement that, post issue to Git Center repository.

---

Example from `|><||>` [repository](/15Z4H5K8YxjqGWpPxMLHWwr6Ve2nR7dz8d):

## Git Center Update

1. Show actions like closing/reopening issue/PR.
2. Follow actions in newsfeed.
3. Editing and comments and issues!
4. Add and remove tags and follow changes in newsfeed.
Issue sorting feature finally arrived at Git Center! Added `Open` and `Closed` tabs. @BinChan:

@Putsan: Answering http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeroexchange.bit/?/1J29rTU6VTtJQXkBPZzTZPjogdGNpfcBkr/1MrESi8JYQqWEVbuRiGE8d41z29PmpT8GT/1514183561872

I am posting this as a comment because ZeroExchange seems broken. [gitcenter.bit/repo/issues/view/?17isV4gG9MmAwfcR6aroBN1nHmovrhodD4/1@1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/issues/view/?17isV4gG9MmAwfcR6aroBN1nHmovrhodD4/1@1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di)

On ZeroNet, all sites are forks. Even ZeroTalk or ZeroExchange are forks of ZeroHello. Only ZeroHello isn't a fork. So usually all sites except ZeroHello have that button.

Imagine you forked ZeroTalk and then @nofish updated some code there. You can manually copy changed files, etc... Or you can just press `Update code` which does what you want.

Though `Update code` is (let me use a git term) fast-forward - I mean, if both fork and original sites were changed, **all your changes will be lost**!

## Git Center Update

1. Show `<title>`
2. Fixed `actions` like opening/closing issue having wrong author
3. Filter issues and PRs by tag
4. Closed/opened issues in different tabs
5. Fixed `12.631 seconds ago` -> `12 seconds ago`
6. Submodule parser now handles GitHub ssh links properly
7. **Critical update on ZeroLib**: Fixed ZeroFS. Reading into ArrayBuffer could cause additional zero byte at the end to be allocated.
Also working on Mercurial support now. Halfway done!

Can anyone download [Git Center repository](/18r929Hq8hE5Pi9Zf7ovMQVyn3WcGfxMgu) for testing? I get no peers found when publishing practically all the time. Wanna make out if this is software error or nobody seeds.

@Binchan: Wanna update your dark theme to work with peeper.bit?

Also, I added some changed like `show comment count on issue list` and `reactions`.
`Sign and publish` button upcoming!
@Nofish: That `Sorry, you cannot delete your own site` makes more problems than it solves. Maybe remove that check at all?
Okay I'm back to the project. Was busy with [ZeroMailProxy](https://github.com/imachug/ZeroMailProxy/) and *something else*.
@missesrobot: On your proxy anyone can un-block Millchan boards. Is it safe enough to host?

## Git Center Update

I'm glad to release this now! **Mercurial support arrives at Git Center!**

This support is still beta, so please send bugs to Git Center Source repo.

You can create a mercurial repo by choosing that on `Create new repository` page.

@krixano: You used VueJS, can you help me with [http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeroexchange.bit/?/1HfXMzGHoz36sQBw7WqLSdxwq1agwWVR27/1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di/1516288139573](/zeroexchange.bit/?/1HfXMzGHoz36sQBw7WqLSdxwq1agwWVR27/1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di/1516288139573) please?

@Nofish: can you help me to build a site please? I'm not getting how to add template inside site. In code I have:

```
siteClone("my_site_address", "hub-template");
```

My file structure is:

```
+ content.json
+ index.html
+ bundle.js
+ hub-template
+---+ index.html
    + index.css
    + data
    +---+ users
    |   +---+ content.json-default
    + content.json-default
```

But clone attempt fails with `No rules`. Should I change something?

For whatever reason I decided to use WikiText format for my ZeroWikipedia. Well, to be honest, that's because I don't want to write `[[]]` handler.

So I didn't find any WikiText parser with template handling and now I'll have to write `{{}}` handler :D
Working on ZeroWikipedia.
Hello @Nofish: I'm working on exporting articles from ZeroWiki to ZeroWikipedia, so I would want to use `fileQuery` feature. Can you look at https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/1261 please?
Importing article from ZeroWiki.

Decided to import `Main Page` from en.wikipedia.org to ZeroWikipedia. Guess what happens?

*P.S. (I hope) I'll release a beta tomorrow. There won't be auto-update-imported-articles feature yet (though I'll add it soon), but it will have a) create article b) edit article c) view history d) import article e) manually reimport article f) create hub g) templates (see those boxes with red and yellow at the left?). Also working on optional files support now.*

@ZeroLSTN: Kiwipedia is about to be released, could you take a look at typos please? You can check [GitHub](https://github.com/imachug/Kiwipedia) repository or [Git Center](/13c2MpR9ztCzVm7r8cTfV9h9FFEEiQ6AKD).
Hey devs, is 1MB-script okay for ZeroNet or should I split it?

Kiwipedia bundle, rendered by webpack bundle analyzer.

UPD forgot to add babel runtime, looks like those chunks will be >1MB together.
Fixed bundle.

**[Kiwipedia Beta](/1KiwiBCVBUcuypVm8FEmUW9YT6fJDXkN9r) is up!**

Please help me to check if it works.

@ZeroLSTN: Some ideas about ZeroLSTN.

By @Gobottheelphant:

> Издания, которые в самом распространенном случае - альбомы. В таком виде это достаточно удобно, чтобы присоединиться к раздаче и соответствует практике торрент трекеров. Жанры слишком объемны для выкладывания одним человеком, и слишком разнородны, чтобы поддерживаться из интереса. Кроме того, деление на жанры весьма неоднозначно.

Translation:

> Editions, which are usually `albums`. This is useful enough to seed and this is the practice of torrect trackers. Instead, genres are too large to be maintained by one person and too different to be wanted to seed. Moreover, some songs may apply to several genres.

```
$ npm install katex --save
+ katex@0.9.0-beta1
added 2 packages and removed 33 packages in 72.124s
```

wtf?

KaTeX - a library I am going to use for `<math>` tags in Kiwipedia - turned out to be 600KB. Moreover, I had to split it to **3 parts** just to make ZeroNet distribute these files w/o problems. Moreover, KaTeX is a third of the whole code!

## Kiwipedia update

Added `<math>` tags and templates.
@Kaffie: Added the feature you were talking about.
@Krixano: What about using `+` prefix for strict search? E.g. `+a b c` matches `a b` or `a c` or `a b c` and `+a -b c d` matches `a c d` and `a c` and `a d`.

Developers!

Is it possible to use local file system for ZeroNet applications? I am building something that needs to hold some private file. I could use localStorage, but I need random access. I could use some FS api my browser provides, but it is non-standard. I could use `data/users/.../file.priv`, but I have to sign `content.json`, so the data may be leaked.

Is there any other way?

Just built another bicycle. Here is another command line argument parser and router (**will be used as part of `ZeroNet-cmd-lib` package, command-line utils for ZeroNet**). Enjoy!

Usage:
```python
import sys
from lib.callable import Callable

class MyApplication(Callable.WithHelp):
	"""
		My Application.

		This help will be shown when "./myapp.py help" is ran.
	"""

	def action(self, *args, **kwargs):
		if len(args) == 0 and len(kwargs) == 0:
			# Redirect to "help" when no arguments were passed.
			raise Callable.Redirect("help")
		else:
			raise Callable.SubCommand

	def actionCmd(self, arg1, arg2):
		"""
			cmd command.

			This help will be shown when "./myapp.py help cmd" is ran. 2 arguments must be passed. Named arguments, e.g. "./myapp.py cmd --arg1 fsdgfd --arg2 fgdgfd" are allowed.
		"""

		print "cmd", arg1, arg2

	def actionCmd2(self, arg1, arg2=1, *arg3):
		"""
			cmd2 command.

			Supports default arguments and *args. An error message will be printed if <1 arguments are passed.
		"""

		print "cmd2", arg1, arg2, "*", arg3

	def actionSearch(self, strict, *args):
		"""
			search

			Use either "search strict ..." or "search unstrict ...". An error message will be shown if there if there is no "actionSearchTheNextWordGoesHere" method.
		"""

		raise Callable.SubCommand

	def actionSearchStrict(self, a):
		pass
	def actionSearchUnstrict(self, a):
		pass

# sys.argv[0] is the path to current script.
MyApplication(sys.argv[1:])
```

Source code: [GitHub](https://github.com/imachug/ZeroNet-cmd-lib/blob/master/lib/callable.py).
Defenitely need some games here. I'm starting to think about remaking [Uplink](https://introversion.co.uk/uplink/) Multiplayer in 0net...

Hello everyone! What about playing Chess or Tic-Tac-Toe on ZeroNet? Just a prototype, many things aren't done yet, but it works!

---

To use 0Play, you must download PeerMessage plugin. To do this, you can either use [@Krixano's installer](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Windows-Exe-Installer/releases/download/1.4/ZeroNetInstaller.exe) or manually download the plugin:

1. Download the ZIP from: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage/archive/master.zip
2. Unpack it to plugins/PeerMessage or core/plugins/PeerMessage or  ZeroNet/plugins/PeerMessage, wherever the `plugins` directory is.
3. Restart ZeroNet
4. Open http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ag6xidDHiPgWoDKhfSx4xFQr6WC3NqxZg/?/

Yet another test site for PeerMessage plugin. **Remember to install it by downloading from [GitHub](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage) and saving to `plugins` directory!**

Now it's Reddit's /r/place on ZeroNet, with realtime update. No limit. Just draw anything you want.

[ZPlace](/1D6f2CvDRhPeEeBAcmqGt3X9z2CkLpmv2V). Enjoy!

Google is going to kill URLs. From the latest Chrome release, `https://m.www.m.www.example.com` is shown as `example.com`.

Are you **for** or **against** it? Post your answers in comments.

# PoC and detailed explanation of "The Vacation" attack is ready.

Detailed info and POC of the "Vacation" sandbox escape bug that was discovered by GitCenter / Krixano / ZeroLSTN 3 weeks ago (fixed in Rev3616+): [**The Vacation** Vurnerability list](/1HcLPSR5ss1ehsqP8kU2Sa2TJyDVcGADTp).

Ask me anything [on ZeroTalk](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1540051200_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di/PoC+and+detailed+explanation).
**Spreading the word about [KxoHub](/1LqcxtENM69yBggxPYLaj87J4bqon5SVwU), a ZeroMe hub for [KxoID](/kxoid.bit) users. Thanks, @krixano!!**

# [StreamZ](/1BTZh5pymEKzMYr3qgDtgr4dMmap77QvEs)

Hello, ZeroNet community! Today @glightstar, @zerolstn, @krixano and me are introducing [StreamZ](/1BTZh5pymEKzMYr3qgDtgr4dMmap77QvEs), a revolutionary live-streaming service for ZeroNet!

1. You need to install **PeerMessage plugin** to send/receive the stream
2. **Recording works on Chrome and Firefox.** Other browsers that support MediaRecorder should work as well (i.e. Opera and Safari Technology Preview, according to caniuse).
3. You can use *Python 2* version of ZeroNet if you are only going to watch videos. If you also want to record them or use chat, you need the **latest** *Python 3* version of ZeroNet, that you can download on [GitHub](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet).

If you have any problems on the installation step, or StreamZ itself bugs, ask me in the comments.

[ZeroTalk](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1555759517_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di/StreamZ)

I've been thinking about writing a series of articles about Elliptic Curve Cryptography. That's a big and difficult topic that's interesting nevertheless. I'll probably also talk about some things that are implementation-related, e.g. compressed keys, how signatures look like and so on. Would you read this?
I started writing some articles about cryptography. [Take a look here](/1FwH89xyniDgy3t6fCWrggLs22MnGPZ5K5). I'll probably write something connected to ZeroNet there as well.
[ZeroNet is ruled by a single person. And this should be fixed](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1562000931_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di/ZeroNet+is+ruled+by+one+person+And+this+should+be+fixed)
Something I'm working on (that's not a full list).
@Kaffie: What would be the best solution to the TLD problem? You said you don't like the current situation, but you haven't given any ideas how to solve it.

## xkcd for ZeroNet is live!

Check it at [xkcd.yo](/xkcd.yo/) (here's [an address-based link](/1XKCDh5XeLm5eN4jM8b1Mk4wKrnUJxV12/) in case you don't have Name.YO).

Currently, the comics aren't mirrored automatically, so I'll have to run a script from time to time; I might set up a cron script later.

Also, xkcd has interactive comics which aren't mirrored (or, rather, only their screenshots are stored). All other comics are mirrored correctly, though.

If you enjoy xkcd and this mirror, please help seed optional files in sidebar.

And, yeah... it has an easter egg.

# Name.YO update

You can now support Name.YO by adding a shield to your site:

## [ZeroNet security, and why I behaved weird recently](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1567261498_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di/ZeroNet+security+and+why+I+behaved+weird+recently)

Recently, I published a few proposals on decentralizing ZeroNet development. Unfortunately, many people were sceptical. I think it's the right time to become honest now. This should give you an explanation of my actions:

[1HnH3JRH6N61MxrtbgLKumLoY3Nb3Y1jS](/1HnH3JRH6N61MxrtbgLKumLoY3Nb3Y1jS/)
...not that nonsense actually

Even if [matrix](https://matrix.org) doesn't have the best interface and is laggy, it's still the best solution for room mirroring. We've just set up (with @blurHY) bidirectional bridges between a Matrix room, a Discord server, a Telegram group, a Gitter room and a Slack channel, and they work almost instantly.

Sidenote: It's interesting how different chats use many different names for the same thing.
Name.YO just went down because both zn.amorgan.xyz and z.hex3.cf are not responding. Do you know other proxies except 0net.io?

# Name.YO update

Name.YO just got an update. I've added some moderation: registered domains can now be recommended or disadvantaged by Name.YO moderators (only me right now). Verified and possibly dangerous domains are marked with icons. I've also added a way to filter all domains / verified and unrated domains / verified domains only.

The reason for such an addition is that a few NSFW domains were added recently, and I didn't want to accidentally open them. Whilst it's not DNS that should do moderation, I believe that this is the best way we have now.

---

And yes, I'm avoiding zite advertisments.

# KxoID needs your help

As you might (or might not) know, [KxoID](/kxoid.bit/) is a semi-decentralized ID provider that turned down because @Krixano --the only person running a registrar service-- left ZeroNet. It has been down for quite a while but none of us actually started serving it. Thus, I'm asking for help among ZeroNetters. I want to get a brief overview on how many people are ready to host it, and how much I trust them.

Please comment if you would like to host KxoID 24/7 or in your free time, whatever you want.

@filips @kusoneko @fant

Please install [BackgroundProcessing](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-BackgroundProcessing/tree/py3) and [PeerMessage](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage/tree/py3) plugins.

Then, download site [1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/). After that, register a KxoID if you don't have it and login. (I've started a server locally temporary so you should be able to do that)

After that, download [this NullPaste](/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di_4) and put it to `0background.py` to the site root. Also put the following to `0config.json` file (again, in the site root):

```json
{
    "level": 2,
    "public_address": "18Mt3CWBpiqJBLsPSu5JxB4B9MeaSwhyJ",
    "privatekey": "Private key goes here. I sent it to you to ZeroMail."
}
```

After that, open [KxoNet](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/), then open devtools (F12) and enter the following:

```
zeroframe.cmd("wrapperPermissionAdd", ["BACKGROUND"]);
```

Accept the permission. KxoID server should now be running. You can check that by opening console/logs and checking for `[KxoNetwork]`.

# KxoNetwork gets a logo

We now have a brand :) I think that's awesome but I have a story to tell you that's connected to the logo.

So I wanted to make something like the image below. I didn't have any tools like Photoshop or GIMP, nor did I want to download them. So I was left with Paint (obviously no) and... SVG! It turned out to be a rather interesting format. The pro is that you can edit (or create) an image just with a text editor, but unfortunately there are too many pitfalls. First, I wanted to make a gradient; but you *can't* make a gradient that follows the direction of a line; instead, you have to make a separate gradient for each line and use `rotate`. But as the rotation is done relative to `(0, 0)`, you have to move the gradient then, so a simple black-to-blue gradient actually looks like this:

```
<linearGradient id="grad2" gradientTransform="rotate(180) translate(-1, 0)">
    <stop offset="0%" stop-color="#000030" />
    <stop offset="100%" stop-color="#0020a0" />
</linearGradient>
```

Then I had an idea of using lines for the three parts of the triangle (because they are mostly lines with a bit strange endings). Looks like that wasn't the right decision. In SVG, you can choose line width but you can't choose the endings (e.g. drawing an ellipse-like line is impossible). Luckily, there are polygons for that -- *but* you can only choose a single color pattern for the polygon and using three gradients is impossible!

After playing with a colored triangle, I tried switching it to gradients. But -- guess what? The two upper parts of the triangle looked well, but the lower one didn't even show up! Strangely, replacing a `(1, 38) - (42, 38)` line with a `(1, 38) - (42, 37.99)` line works well!

SVG could be a really useful format, but, unfortunately, it turned out to be only editable by machines, even though it's good old XML.

Test via PyPy

# Running ZeroNet on PyPy

First: that's possible. Second: that's useless.

Here's a comparison table:

```
                       CPython  PyPy
hdPrivatekey            1.21    1.87
sign                    0.42    0.72
btctools verify         0.07    0.11
openssl verify          0.88    0.61
libsecp256k1 verify     2.96    2.16
sha256                  0.99    0.78
sha512                  0.70    1.20
os.urandom(256)         0.42    0.21
pack                    1.85    7.14
unpack                  2.40    2.48
streaming unpack        1.69    2.19
streaming unpack        29.91   2.80
Open                    2.08    0.93
Insert                  1.07    0.89
Buffered insert         1.03    0.67
Indexed query           1.78    1.34
Not indexed query       2.26    0.92
Like query              3.39    0.73
Zip pack                0.48    0.10
Zip unpack              1.42    0.22
Tar.gz pack             1.20    0.29
Tar.gz unpack           0.80    0.17
Tar.bz2 pack            1.21    0.60
Tar.bz2 unpack          1.19    0.36
Tar.xz pack             1.15    0.52
Tar.xz unpack           0.85    0.15
```

So, the only things that PyPy optimizes are:

- hdPrivatekey -- only used when creating sites or downloading a site first time;
- sign -- just a little bit; you seldom sign so it doesn't matter much;
- btctools verify -- doesn't matter because secp256k1 verify is used by default;
- msgpack -- this one is used often for network communication, but it doesn't matter much because the network speed matters a lot more.

'What could possibly go wrong?' npm infrastructure: licensed, tested, linted, CI'd, documented project with several contributors... that is 735 bytes compiled. Out of them:

- 130 bytes are comments
- 173 bytes are a wrapper for different environments (NodeJS-like require, UMD, browser)
- 432 bytes are actual code

The funny thing is that inbuilt `Array` usage (instead of this stack library) overhead is lower than those 432 bytes.

Summing up my investigation on uploading files from browser to ZeroNet via websockets:

- The browser is slow
- `gevent-websocket` is slow
- websockets are slow

# 🤦

I've just found the bottleneck in Python websocket implementation:

```
for i in range_type(self.length):
    payload[i] ^= self.mask[i % 4]
```

It takes Python over a second to xor a 1 MiB array with a constant. Removing these two lines increases websocket throughput from 40 Mbps to around 1700 Mbps.

It's Python after all.

We've recently switched to gevent_ws for websocket communication and sslcrypto for cryptography. Both libraries work well on all the devices I have, and the patch to make it work on weird setups (like canewsin's ZeroNet client with a weird OpenSSL library) are waiting to be merged.

This means that we've got rid of all GPLv3-incompatible libraries. Perhaps the only thing left is to check if we can legally switch now!

# [The Sad Story of Terminal Emulators](/1FwH89xyniDgy3t6fCWrggLs22MnGPZ5K5/?Post:11:The+Sad+Story+of+Terminal+Emulators)

> ISO 2022 locking escape sequences oh flying
> spaghetti monster please kill me now.
> *— Actual USENIX peer review from the Mosh paper*

Terminals were invented before many of us were born, in the ancient times where people cared about standards, and browser incompatibilities weren't a thing. And yet, overcoming terminal problems is what I have to spend half of the time when I write CLI tools. The features in use are few in number: named colors, RGB true-color, font weight, cursor movement and position saving/restoring, so I didn't expect any problems when switching a terminal emulator. And yet all of them provide render text differently.

[Read more](/1FwH89xyniDgy3t6fCWrggLs22MnGPZ5K5/?Post:11:The+Sad+Story+of+Terminal+Emulators)

---

A useful script for ZeroNet. Lists the sites with the largest non-user data files. Execute from `data` directory.

find . -maxdepth 1 -name '1*' -exec bash -c "jq .files[].size {}/content.json | awk '{ sum += \$1 } END { print sum }' | tr -d '\n'; echo ' {}'" \; | sort -rn | head

# Namecoin is dead, long live addresses

Namecoin itself is a good drop-in replacement of DNS for decentralized networks, so it was natural to use it on ZeroNet. But it's only today when we realize that we were solving the wrong problem all the time.

Unlike Clearnet where you have to type facebook.com every five minutes to open a social network, ZeroNet has a homepage which shows all the sites you have downloaded -- ZeroHello. Show me any person who types `http://127.0.0.1:43110/sitename.bit` in the address bar instead of typing `sitename` to the site name filter on ZeroHello. The only moment when people actually use Namecoin is when sharing site links with others: it's easier to say 'sitename dot bit` instead of 'one capital A small b small c...'. Naturally, once you download the site, you don't use the domain at all, until you want to share the site with others.

So, what is the difference from Clearnet? In Clearnet, domains are mandatory and there are search engines. In ZeroNet, addresses are almost always enough to work (inefficiently but still) and there are no search engines. On Clearnet, there is archive.org and such, on ZeroNet many sites are run by enthusiasts and are easily forgotten.

ZeroNet is in a unique position when there is a possibility not to use domains the wrong way, and everyone uses them so. The officially recommended 'best practices' are to add `domain` field to content.json, which redirects everyone to the wrong address, should the domain be squatted. Also, ZeroName has a 'feature': expired domains still work until they are redirected by another person. **ZeroNet makes it look like everything is okay until domains break, and recommends doing so.**

What can we do about it? First, remove `domain` field from your sites immediately, although you may add the domain name to your blog sidebar or something. Second, do not use domains in hyperlinks, use raw addresses instead. Third, if you still need a domain, give a chance to non-expiring domains such as the ones provided by [Name.YO](/1NAMEz7stUPZErkV1d3yLkVWQFa4PTqDNv/).

# How sites break because of Namecoin

Does anyone remember ZeroSearch here? That's an old site indexer, created back when ZeroNet didn't have user content. It was hosted on zerosearch.bit/1ZeroeuDnL2jNS6t1epQa1SPvC91KG8ER. The author thought that `1ZeroeuDnL2jNS6t1epQa1SPvC91KG8ER` in the address bar doesn't look nice so they had a redirect from Bitcoin site to zerosearch.bit.

Guess what? A little bit later zerosearch.bit was bought by someone (probably Kaffie, though don't quote me on that) who changed the domain address to Kaffiene's. So now, even if you visit ZeroSearch by address, not by domain, you're still redirected to Kaffiene and the only way to use the site (or at least find out whether it works -- it doesn't) is to manually edit index.html.

Moral: don't count on Namecoin.

# [btccaserestore](https://github.com/imachug/btccaserestore)

Here we go, a cool tool I've made during the weekend. This one helps you restore a Bitcoin or ZeroNet address if you've messed up your case-insensitive filesystem, received an address via an old teletype or something.

```
$ ./caserestore 1a1zp1ep5qgefi2dmptftl5slmv7divfna
1A1zP1eP5QGefi2DMPTfTL5SLmv7DivfNa
```

Implementation details: the tool looks fairly simple but the code is around 500 lines because of all the optimizations. For example, the bruteforce order is a Hilbert curve constructed with Gray code to minimize slow long integer addition calls, SHA-256 of every four strings is computed in parallel using AVX2 256-bit registers *(I'd go with hashing eight strings using 512-bit registers if only my CPU supported AVX-512 instruction set)*, the search space is divided into chunks evenly to maximize compare-per-hash ratio, etc.
Happy 13/01/2020, everyone!

@Piloth The Mack: Oh, I thought that you might have written a comment and then replaced it with `.` to delete it. Anyways, as for the service: you need a standard ZeroNet client (v0.7.0 or above) and two plugins (namely, BackgroundProcessing and PeerMessage). You'll then have to follow a few actions (in this port) to run KxoID. So there's no additional software to install and you don't need any new hardware -- you can just run KxoID next to your ZeroNet client.

@Mg0: Basically, you generate a single big key of the same size as the message. Then when you're ready to send the message, you XOR it with the key and the receiver XORes it back. The idea is that as long as a single key is not used twice for different messages and the key is long enough, there's (provably) no way to recover the message.
